abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Economic Reform
            Technical Assistance Project in Sri Lanka were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory. Lessons learned included: the project team
            took client ownership very seriously, making a real effort
            to listen to officials and stakeholders and tailoring the
            project to their needs. In all areas, Sri Lankans called the
            shots and sought Bank technical advice only when necessary.
            The project incorporated an unallocated pool of resources,
            the Challenge Fund. Although initially received with a
            healthy degree of skepticism, the Challenge Fund has
            provided space for successive administrations to alter the
            course of the reforms and still be able to benefit from Bank
            funding without having to design a new project. It has also
            helped the Bank respond almost immediately with post-tsunami
            assistance. Realizing that each administration has a small
            window of opportunity to push reform initiatives, the Bank
            committed to a quick turnaround on all Technical Assistance
            (TA) requests and after initial teething problems was able
            to come to a two to three day turnaround for all requests.
            Establishing capacity to handle the procurement and
            management of more than 100 consultancies in the first two
            years of operation was critical to success. It also meant
            that line ministries could focus on management of the reform
            and leave the administrative aspects to others.
